author: Ray Jablonski, Northeast Ohio Media Group
title: Stock futures pointing down; toxic spill affects Southwest water supply; China devalues currency: A.M. Business News Links
text:
Stock market news:
Stock futures are pointing down and European markets are mostly declining in early trading. Dow Jones futures are behind 99 points, S&P 500 futures are declining 11 points and Nasdaq futures are down 9.25 points. ( CNN Money )
Global stocks and Asian currencies fell today after China unexpectedly devalued the yuan in response to weakening trade and growth. ( Associated Press )
Gold prices turned higher today, reversing a drop that came after the surprise decision by China to devalue its currency. ( MarketWatch )
U.S. business news:
Colorado and New Mexico declared stretches of the Animas and San Juan rivers to be disaster areas as an orange-colored mine waste stream made its way downstream toward Lake Powell in Utah after the spill last week at the abandoned Gold King mine near Silverton, Colorado. ( Associated Press )
U.S. small business confidence rebounded in July from a 15-month low as owners anticipated solid sales and inventory growth, providing another boost to the economic outlook for the third quarter. ( Reuters )
The U.S. Postal Service Monday reported a net loss of $586 million this spring, a big improvement for the cash-strapped agency compared with a nearly $2 billion loss during the same period last year. ( Associated Press )
Shell is set to restart its controversial hunt for Arctic oil, three years after the company's last ill-fated venture north. ( The Guardian )
The IRS is warning taxpayers to be vigilant and on high alert in the wake of evolving tax scams. ( Forbes )
Technology news:
AT&T has wasted no time in leveraging its now vast presence in the TV delivery market to try and boost its communications business, announcing DirecTV customers will be entitled to $500 in credits for each line they switch to AT&T. ( Forbes )
Norton antivirus maker Symantec said it would sell its data storage business, Veritas, for $8 billion in cash to a group including Carlyle Group and Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC. ( Reuters )
Financial services software company Envestnet announced Monday it has acquired financial data mining and technology company Yodlee in a cash and stock transaction valued at $18.88 per share, or approximately $660 million. ( Fortune )
The number of consumers using ad blocking software worldwide has increased 41 percent year-on-year to 198 million monthly active users, according to a report published by PageFair and Adobe. ( Business Insider )
World business news:
China devalued its tightly controlled currency today following a slump in trade, allowing the yuan's biggest one-day decline in a decade. ( Associated Press )
Greece has agreed to a bailout deal "in principle" with its creditors, the European Commission has said, and now political approval is required. ( BBC News )
Japan has restarted a nuclear reactor for the first time under new safety standards put in place since the Fukushima disaster in 2011, as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe seeks to reassure a nervous public the industry is now safe. ( Reuters )
German economic sentiment unexpectedly deteriorated in August, hitting its lowest level since November last year, a sign the economic upswing in Europe's largest economy is losing momentum. ( MarketWatch )
